Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Great Earthquakes, Megathrust Phenomenology and Continental Dynamics in the Southern Andes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of the project is to understand the processes that created and now drive evolution of the modern Andes. In order to do that, we must understand the spatial and temporal variability of stresses generated in the upper plate by coupling at the plate interface and by viscous drag of the asthenosphere. Specifically, the project will focus on the 2010 Mw 8.8 Maule earthquake in Chile, the earthquake cycle along the Nazca-South America plate interface, orogenesis of the Andean system, and its relationship to crustal deformation and mantle flow.

The project is structured around two main themes:

? How does megathrust phenomenology influence or control the architecture, from forearc to backarc, of the Andean orogeny?
? How do geological materials, shallow structure and slab/mantle dynamics influence or control the behavior and evolution of the megathrust?

The PI group will use GPS and INSAR to examine post-seismic transients and combine these with co-seismic data. They will combine many sources of GPS data (German - GFZ and US groups) that have been collected from 1993 to present over the entire orogen in an effort to develop a synoptic model. This includes data from 33 cGPS stations installed in Chile with NSF-RAPID funds immediately following the Maule earthquake. The regional extent of new analysis will include the rupture zone from the 1960 Mw 9.5 earthquake, which still shows post-seismic transient deformation.

Among the important geodynamic processes that the project will address are (1) time-variable deformation in the aftermath of a great subduction-zone earthquake; (2) improved models of plate interface rheology and their implications for plate boundary earthquake cycles; and (3) interaction between plate boundary and intraplate deformation over time-scales from decadal to geological.

In addition to GPS and InSAR observation of surface deformation, the project brings to bear a number of state-of-the-art observational and modeling approaches; earthquake location and source mechanism determination; geological and geochemical constraints on uplift and erosion rates; inversion for geometric and rheological parameters associated with the plate interface; and large-scale geodynamic modeling. The investigator team is highly qualified to take on these activities, and has a strong track record in previous work in the area. They have developed a strong set of collaborations, both in-country and with other international researchers working in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2010 a giant (magnitude 8.8) earthquake (EQ) occured in the Maule region of South-Central Chile. At the time it was the fifth largest earthquake to have occured any where on Earth in the modern instrumental era, and it offered the greatest opportunity to date to observe the deformation associated with such earthquakes, because the this region was much more accessible that the region affected by the 2004 Aceh, Indonesia event (famous for producing the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami) and already had a lot of GPS infrastructure near the northern and southern ends of the rupture zone. Unfortunately, the central portion of the 500-600 km rupture zone underlying and offshore from the Maule sector, was an area with very few GPS stations. NSF funded an effort to build 40 new CGPS stations in the Maule region and nearby parts of Argentina using a RAPID award in order to observe postseimic deformation in unprecedented detail. Following the emergency geodetic response, which was led by OSU, NSF funded this project to maintain that network for the following five year,s and use the GPS data, InSAR observations and other geophysical and geological data sets to study the M 8.8 Maule event, so as to caste new light on the physics of great subduction zone earthquakes.  This collaborative project involving (initially) four US universties engaged with local, French and German geodesists and geophysicists, pooling large amounts of data, and collaborating in the analysis of these observations. We have produced the second largest dataset for a giant megathrust event, second only to that collected in Japan for the 2011 M 9.1 earthquake.  The Maule data set is being analyze by our collaborative team, but also by dozens of other research groups all around the world. The scientific GPS networks are multiple-use infrastructures being us to support mapping and surveying, as well as an Earthquake and Tsunami Early Warning System, in addition to supporting basic research.

This research has produced more than 15 peer-reviewed publication by the main collaborative team, and at least as many by other researchers in other parts of the world.

In terms of our own investigations the two most interesting outcomes are probanly these:  (1) when observing the regional deformation produced by giant EQs like the Maule event, both close to the rupture area and as far as 1,000 km away, the traditional flat, homogeneous dislocation models in use since the mid 1980s are inadequate because they do not capute much of the essential physics. It is necessary to model earthquakes using Earth models which are spherical, layered and self-grativating. At present less than 1% of all published papers analyzing earthquake deformation use dislocation models featuring all three characteristics. (2) In the 1970's it was realized that postseismic deformation could be explained in terms of afterslip on the same megathrust surface that had ruptures coseismically, often at greater depth, or by assuming the deformation was produced by the viscous relaxation of the stress field produced by the main event. Afterslip is restricted to the plate boundry producing the main earthquake, so it is a highly localized process, but the earth would respond elastically do this asiesmic slip field, just as it did to the coseismic slip.  In contrast, viscoelastic relaxation would involve the relaxation of coseisic stresses via viscous flow of rocks, mostly in the asthenosphere, over a much larger area and volume. In the first decade of this centrury, geophysical theorists developed a consensus around the idea that in the first few months or even few years after a great earthquake, postseismic deformation was very largely driven by afterslip, but subsequentl it woud be driven in larger part by viscoelastic relaxation. Analysis of the 2010 Maule event, and the 2011 Japan event, seem to lend support to a minority view, that afterslip may dominate postseismic transients for almost one decade. What does this matter? But the physics of these two processes is completely different, and any chance we have to develop practical earthquake predictions methodologies has to be based on a fairly complete physical understanding of the earthquke deformation cycle.
